title: La presidenta de México dice que las fuerzas militares de EE. UU. no son bienvenidas en su país
description: La presidenta Sheinbaum negó que EE. UU. vaya a utilizar al ejército en territorio mexicano, en respuesta a la noticia de que Trump ordenó al Pentágono que atacara a los cárteles de la droga.
content:
La presidenta de México dice que las fuerzas militares de EE. UU. no son bienvenidas en su país La presidenta Sheinbaum negó que EE. UU. vaya a utilizar al ejército en territorio mexicano, en respuesta a la noticia de que Trump ordenó al Pentágono que atacara a los cárteles de la droga. El presidente Donald Trump ordenó el viernes al Pentágono que atacara a los cárteles de la droga. Si el Pentágono planea desplegar soldados en México, podría tensar los lazos hasta su peor punto en décadas. 8 de agosto de 2025 a las

La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, negó el viernes que Estados Unidos vaya a utilizar sus fuerzas armadas en territorio mexicano, en respuesta a la noticia de que el presidente Trump había ordenado al Pentágono que enfrentara a los cárteles de la droga que Estados Unidos considera organizaciones terroristas. “Estados Unidos no va a venir a México con los militares. Cooperamos, colaboramos, pero no va a haber invasión. Eso está descartado, absolutamente descartado”, dijo. “Ni es parte de ningún acuerdo, ni mucho menos”. Y añadió: “Cuando lo han llegado a plantear, siempre hemos dicho que no”. Sigue sin estar claro qué planes está elaborando el Pentágono para una posible acción, y la orden plantea cuestiones jurídicas sobre varios temas. Los funcionarios mexicanos han rechazado rotundamente, en público y en privado, las sugerencias de una acción militar estadounidense contra los cárteles de la droga en territorio mexicano. En su conferencia de prensa matutina, Sheinbaum dijo que leería la orden del presidente Trump, pero negó que existiera riesgo alguno de que el ejército estadounidense pudiera invadir México. Si el Pentágono planea utilizar fuerzas en México o en cualquier otro lugar de América Latina, podría tensar los lazos hasta su peor punto en décadas, en un momento en que los países de la región intentan colaborar estrechamente con Estados Unidos en cuestiones importantes como la migración y la lucha contra el narcotráfico. Dependiendo de lo que haga Estados Unidos, México podría retirar su cooperación en temas como la seguridad y la migración si la Casa Blanca actúa unilateralmente, según tres personas familiarizadas con las ideas del gobierno. Estas personas hablaron bajo condición de anonimato para discutir deliberaciones internas delicadas. “Necesitan la cooperación de México y necesitan que el Estado y la sociedad mexicanos funcionen. Esto no es Afganistán, donde el Estado está roto y puedes hacer lo que quieras porque hay un vacío”, dijo Arturo Rocha, quien dimitió a finales del año pasado de la Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores mexicana, donde se encargaba de las relaciones con Estados Unidos. “Este ha sido siempre el temor más profundo de México, esta sensación constante de que podríamos ser invadidos de nuevo por Estados Unidos”, añadió. “Tendría implicaciones importantes en términos de cooperación con Estados Unidos en el futuro. La presidenta ha dejado claro que nuestra soberanía es una línea roja”. Las autoridades mexicanas pensaban que habían llegado a un punto de inflexión con el gobierno de Trump en la lucha contra el narcotráfico, tras haber lanzado una enérgica ofensiva contra el Cártel de Sinaloa, uno de los mayores productores mundiales de fentanilo. El cártel, uno de los más antiguos y poderosos de México, ha sufrido graves pérdidas mientras Sheinbaum desplegaba cientos de soldados para combatirlo. Miembros de la Marina mexicana vigilan la escena de un crimen a principios de este año. Las autoridades mexicanas han rechazado las sugerencias de una acción militar estadounidense contra los cárteles de la droga en territorio mexicano. Los funcionarios estadounidenses parecían satisfechos con los progresos, y habían pregonado un descenso del 50 por ciento en las incautaciones de fentanilo en los últimos meses en comparación con los mismos meses del año pasado. No está claro si el descenso se debe a que los cárteles se sienten presionados y frenan la producción o a que encuentran formas nuevas e innovadoras de eludir la detección. El embajador de Estados Unidos en México, Ronald Johnson, se jactó a finales del mes pasado de que el descenso de las incautaciones de fentanilo se debía “a una frontera segura” y a una “mayor colaboración entre Estados Unidos y México”. Bajo el “liderazgo” de Trump y Sheinbaum, “los cárteles están quebrando y nuestros países son más seguros gracias a ello”, dijo Johnson en la plataforma de redes sociales X. Washington también ha cooperado con México en materia de migración, que alcanzó mínimos históricos a principios de este año y fue un tema central de las campañas presidenciales de Trump. La frontera entre Estados Unidos y México ha estado tranquila durante el último año, en gran parte porque México intensificó sus esfuerzos para impedir que los migrantes cruzaran su territorio. En junio se registraron los pasos fronterizos más bajos de la historia, según los datos de Aduanas y Protección Fronteriza, con 6072 migrantes interceptados en la frontera suroeste con México, frente a los 83.532 del mismo mes de 2024. Si Trump adopta una postura militar estadounidense más agresiva en México, como el despliegue de soldados estadounidenses o el uso de drones de ataque, podría ser políticamente desastroso para Sheinbaum. Los mexicanos son extremadamente sensibles al ejército estadounidense debido a la historia de intervención, guerra y apropiación de territorio por parte de Estados Unidos. Sheinbaum ha disfrutado de altos índices de aprobación, que rondan el 75 por ciento, pero existen profundas divisiones y competencia por el poder dentro de su partido. Aunque los mexicanos han apoyado sus esfuerzos por negociar con el gobierno de Trump una serie de cuestiones, desde la migración hasta los aranceles, una acción militar estadounidense dentro de México probablemente la golpearía duramente, según los analistas. También podría debilitar su capacidad para negociar con Trump sobre futuras cuestiones bilaterales, añadieron. El Cártel de Sinaloa, uno de los más poderosos de México, ha sufrido graves pérdidas mientras la presidenta Sheinbaum ha desplegado cientos de soldados para combatirlo. La guerra contra el narcotráfico en México ha sido históricamente liderada por el Departamento de Justicia de Estados Unidos y su agencia antinarcóticos, la Administración para el Control de Drogas. Pero ese esfuerzo se ha llevado a cabo en estrecha colaboración con las autoridades mexicanas. Y el secretismo en torno a la directiva del Pentágono ha suscitado dudas sobre si Estados Unidos podría utilizar la fuerza militar de forma unilateral, sin el conocimiento previo de México, un escenario que podría dañar la confianza laboriosamente construida entre las autoridades de ambos países. “Los beneficios a corto plazo se verán superados con creces por los costos a largo plazo”, dijo Craig Deare, exagregado militar de la embajada estadounidense en México en la década de 1990. “México ha desconfiado de nosotros durante décadas, y hubo un deshielo en la relación que comenzó en la década de 1990″, dijo. “Esa desconfianza podría volver a surgir ahora”. Deare advirtió que hay pocos indicios sobre el tipo de acción que podría emprender el ejército, ya sea al utilizar drones letales o desplegar fuerzas. Estados Unidos ha utilizado durante mucho tiempo drones para hallar redes de producción y contrabando de drogas dentro de México, pero esos programas encubiertos no estaban autorizados a emprender acciones letales. Funcionarios mexicanos han advertido al gobierno de Trump que los programas de drones letales que Estados Unidos lleva a cabo en lugares como Afganistán y Pakistán, donde los grupos terroristas suelen ser objetivo de ataques en zonas rurales, se enfrentarían a circunstancias y riesgos muy diferentes. En México, los cárteles suelen estar arraigados en centros urbanos densamente poblados, lo que aumenta las probabilidades de que se produzcan bajas civiles, y hay muchos más ciudadanos mexicoestadounidenses con doble nacionalidad y sus familiares que viven en lugares que podrían ser objetivo de ataques. “Si Estados Unidos hace esto sin el consentimiento de México, la relación retrocederá cien años”, dijo Todd Robinson, quien fue subsecretario de Estado para Asuntos Internacionales de Narcóticos y Aplicación de la Ley en el Departamento de Estado. Dijo que el ejército estadounidense no tiene las relaciones que otras partes del gobierno estadounidense habían desarrollado con las autoridades mexicanas a lo largo de muchos años. “Trabajamos juntos para construir casos, al compartir información de inteligencia, eso es lo que construye una relación a largo plazo”, dijo, y añadió: “No hay forma de conseguir una buena relación si les metes al ejército estadounidense por la garganta”. Maria Abi-Habib es corresponsal de investigación radicada en Ciudad de México y cubre América Latina.
translation:
The president of Mexico says that the US military forces are not welcome in her country, President Sheinbaum denied that the US will use the army in Mexican territory, in response to the news that Trump ordered the Pentagon to attack the drug cartels. President Donald Trump ordered the Pentagon to attack the drug cartels. If the Pentagon plans to deploy soldiers in Mexico, could tighten the ties to its worst point in decades. August 8, 2025 at

The president of Mexico, Claudia Sheinbaum, denied Friday that the United States will use her armed forces in Mexican territory, in response to the news that President Trump had ordered the Pentagon to face the drug cartels that the United States considers terrorist organizations. "The United States will not come to Mexico with the military. We cooperate, we collaborate, but there will be no invasion. That is discarded, absolutely discarded," he said. "It is not part of any agreement, much less." He added: "When they have come to raise it, we have always said no." It still is not clear what plans is preparing the pentagon for a possible action, and the order raises legal issues on various issues. Mexican officials have flatly rejected, in public and private, the suggestions of an American military action against drug cartels in Mexican territory. In his morning press conference, Sheinbaum said he would read the order of President Trump, but denied that there was any risk that the US army could invade Mexico. If the Pentagon plans to use forces in Mexico or anywhere else in Latin America, you could tighten ties until its worst point in decades, at a time when the countries of the region try to collaborate closely with the United States in important issues such as migration and the fight against drug trafficking. Depending on what the United States does, Mexico could withdraw its cooperation on issues such as security and migration if the White House acts unilaterally, according to three people familiar with government ideas. These people spoke about anonymity to discuss delicate internal deliberations. "They need the cooperation of Mexico and need Mexican State and society to work. This is not Afghanistan, where the State is broken and you can do what you want because there is a vacuum," said Arturo Rocha, who resigned at the end of last year of the Mexican Foreign Secretariat, where he was in charge of relations with the United States. "This has always been the deepest fear of Mexico, this constant feeling that we could be invaded again by the United States," he added. "It would have important implications in terms of cooperation with the United States in the future. The president has made it clear that our sovereignty is a red line." The Mexican authorities thought they had reached a turning point with the Trump government in the fight against drug trafficking, after having launched an energetic offensive against the Sinaloa Cartel, one of Fentanil's greatest world producers. The cartel, one of the oldest and most powerful in Mexico, has suffered serious losses while Sheinbaum deployed hundreds of soldiers to fight it. Members of the Mexican Navy watch the scene of a crime earlier this year. The Mexican authorities have rejected the suggestions of an American military action against drug cartels in Mexican territory. American officials seemed satisfied with progress, and had proclaimed a 50 percent decrease in fentanyl seizures in recent months compared to the same months last year. It is not clear if the descent is because the cartels feel pressured and slow down the production or that they find new and innovative ways to avoid detection. The United States ambassador to Mexico, Ronald Johnson, boasted at the end of last month that the decline in fentanyl seizures was "to a safe border" and a "greater collaboration between the United States and Mexico." Under the "leadership" of Trump and Sheinbaum, "the cartels are breaking and our countries are safer thanks to this," Johnson said on the X. Washington social network. The border between the United States and Mexico has been quiet during the last year, in large part because Mexico intensified its efforts to prevent migrants from crossing their territory. In June, the lowest border crossings in history were recorded, according to customs and border protection data, with 6072 migrants intercepted on the southwest border with Mexico, compared to 83,532 of the same month of 2024. If Trump adopts a more aggressive US military stance in Mexico, such as the deployment of American soldiers or the use of attack drones, it could be politically disastrous for Sheinbaum. Mexicans are extremely sensitive to the US army due to the history of intervention, war and appropriation of territory by the United States. Sheinbaum has enjoyed high approval rates, which are around 75 percent, but there are deep divisions and competition for power within their party. Although Mexicans have supported their efforts to negotiate with the Trump government a series of issues, from migration to tariffs, an American military action within Mexico would probably hit it harshly, according to analysts. He could also weaken his ability to negotiate with Trump on future bilateral issues, they added. The Sinaloa Cartel, one of the most powerful in Mexico, has suffered serious losses while President Sheinbaum has deployed hundreds of soldiers to combat it. The war on drug trafficking in Mexico has historically been led by the United States Department of Justice and its Anti -Narcotics Agency, the Drug Control Administration. But that effort has been carried out in close collaboration with the Mexican authorities. And the secretism around the Pentagon directive has raised doubts about whether the United States could use the military force unilaterally, without the prior knowledge of Mexico, a scenario that could damage confidence laboriously built between the authorities of both countries. "The short -term benefits will be far exceeded by long -term costs," said Craig Deare, an exaggerated military of the US embassy in Mexico in the 1990s. "Mexico has distrusted us for decades, and there was a thaw in the relationship that began in the 1990 Type of action that the Army could undertake, either by using lethal drones or deploying forces. They are usually the objective of attacks in rural areas, they would face very different circumstances and risks. He will retreat a hundred years, ”said Todd Robinson, who was Undersecretary of State for International Narcotics Affairs and application of the law in the State Department. He said that the US army does not have the relations that other parts of the US government had developed with the Mexican authorities over many years. "There is no way to get a good relationship if you put the American army through their throat."
translatedTitle: The president of Mexico says that US military forces are not welcome in her country
translatedDescription: President Sheinbaum denied that the US will use the army in Mexican territory, in response to the news that Trump ordered the Pentagon to attack the drug cartels.
translatedSummary: The president of Mexico, Claudia Sheinbaum, has stated that the US military is not welcome in her country and that there will be no invasion. This comes after President Donald Trump ordered the Pentagon to attack the drug cartels. If the Pentagon plans to deploy soldiers in Mexico, this could tighten ties to its worst point in decades. Mexican officials have rejected suggestions of an American military action against drug cartels in Mexican territory. Mexico could withdraw its cooperation on issues such as security and migration if the White House acts unilaterally, according to three people familiar with government ideas. The tensions could negatively impact the future of cooperation between Mexico and the United States. Analysts suggest that an aggressive US military stance could be politically disastrous for Mexico, which is highly sensitive due to its history of intervention by the US.

scraped_sources.text:
I am an investigative correspondent for The New York Times reporting on Latin America. I am based in Mexico City.
What I Cover
I focus on corruption across Latin America, from widespread government rot to the cartels that terrorize civilians in their quest to push drugs across the world. The facts have shown that institutional greed and organized crime have caused many of the region’s most pressing issues, from migration to the drug trade.
My Background
I joined The Times in 2018 in India as a correspondent covering South Asia. In 2021, I moved to Mexico City to become the bureau chief, leading our coverage for Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean.
I previously worked at The Wall Street Journal where I was a correspondent in Afghanistan from 2010 to 2013. My investigative work in Kabul led to a congressional probe into the conduct of a three-star U.S. general. I was also a roving reporter in the Middle East from 2013 to 2018, covering the Arab Spring and the rise of terror groups that emerged at that time. Before I became a journalist, I studied at Concordia University in Montreal.
I am a two-time Polk winner for my work in Latin America and the Middle East and a Pulitzer Prize finalist. I also won an Overseas Press Club award for a 2023 investigation into corporate greed and environmental damage in India.
I grew up in Lebanon and in Washington, D.C., and learned quickly that there are many sides to every story. But my childhood in Roumieh, a small village in Lebanon’s mountains, showed me how big decisions made in Washington can affect the lives of ordinary people thousands of miles away, a topic I’ve chased since.
My last name roughly translates to “father of lovers.”
Journalistic Ethics
My most important duty is to get it right. I pride myself in talking to as many people as possible to represent as many sides of a story as possible. I protect sources who want to remain anonymous for fear of harm or retribution, and I corroborate what people tell me. Accuracy is important and I correct any mistakes.
Contact Me
You can email me or reach out on Signal, Twitter or Instagram.

Encounter data includes U.S. Border Patrol (USBP) Title 8 Apprehensions, Office of Field Operations (OFO) Title 8 Inadmissibles, and Title 42 Expulsions. Data is available for the Northern Land Border, Southwest Land Border, and Nationwide (i.e., air, land, and sea modes of transportation) encounters.
Title 8 Enforcement Actions refers to apprehensions or inadmissibles processed under CBP’s immigration authority. Inadmissibles refers to individuals encountered at ports of entry (POEs) by OFO who are seeking lawful admission into the United States (U.S.) but are determined to be inadmissible, individuals presenting themselves to seek humanitarian protection under our laws, and individuals who withdraw an application for admission and return to their countries of origin within a short timeframe. Apprehensions refers to the physical control or temporary detainment of a person by USBP between POEs who is not lawfully in the U.S. which may or may not result in an arrest.
Title 42 Expulsions refers to individuals encountered by USBP and OFO and expelled to the country of last transit or home country in the interest of public health under Title 42 U.S.C. 265 from March 21, 2020 to May 11, 2023.
Demographics for USBP and OFO include:
- Accompanied Minors (AM)
- Individuals in a Family Unit (FMUA)
- Single Adults
- Unaccompanied Alien Children (UAC) / Single Minors
To access the data used to build these dashboards, please visit the CBP Data Portal.
Data is extracted from live CBP systems and data sources. Statistical information is subject to change due to corrections, systems changes, change in data definition, additional information, or encounters pending final review. Final statistics are available at the conclusion of each fiscal year.

At Entry: Refers to an alien who has entered the United States without admission and has not yet reached his/her destination, regardless of the amount of time since entry.
At Large: Refers to an alien who has illegally entered the United States, has already reached their destination, and is encountered or who was legally admitted and has since overstayed their permitted time, illegally remaining in the U.S.

Note: Internet Explorer has problems displaying the following charts. Please use another browser (Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge) to view. When using a mobile device, the charts are best displayed in landscape mode.
U.S. Border Patrol and Office of Field Operations Encounters by State
Note: Nationwide encounters are the sum of CBP encounters across all areas of responsibility including Northern Land Border, Southwest Land Border, OFO non-land border ports of entry (e.g., airports, seaports), and USBP sectors that do not share a land border with Canada or Mexico (e.g., Miami Sector). This data is available for further review and download on the Nationwide Encounters Public Data Portal page.
U.S. Border Patrol and Office of Field Operations Encounters
To ensure that law enforcement sensitive statistics are not publicly released, modifications to data filters have been made that may alter the format of data previously obtained from this dashboard.
For additional years of Southwest Land Border encounter data, visit the Southwest Land Border Encounters webpage.

argos_summary: La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, ha rechazado la posibilidad de que Estados Unidos utilice fuerzas militares en su territorio, en respuesta a la orden del presidente Trump de atacar a los cárteles de la droga. Sheinbaum enfatizó que no habrá invasión y que la cooperación entre ambos países se mantendrá, pero advirtió que cualquier acción unilateral de EE. UU. podría dañar las relaciones bilaterales. La situación plantea preocupaciones sobre la soberanía de México y la confianza en la colaboración en temas como la migración y la lucha contra el narcotráfico.
